'I got to say goodbye': Mum opens up over last words before daughter's death Yahoo New Zealand Share Share I got to say goodbye : Mum opens up over last words before daughter s death - Yahoo New Zealand A devastated mother has opened up over the conversation she had with her daughter moments before she died at the scene of a car crash. Close 'I got to say goodbye': Mum opens up over last words before daughter's death UP NEXT VIDEO 'I got to say goodbye': Mum opens up over last words before daughter's death. Source: NZME 'I got to say goodbye': Mum opens up over last words before daughter's death 
Blenheim woman Jayne Glover received a phone call ever mother dreads - your child has been in a serious car crash. 
Mrs Glover recalled the moment she got to say goodbye to Lara, who is described as "bubbly and outgoing". 
She received a phone call from a family friend who was at the scene when the vehicle carrying Lara and seven teens rolled on State Highway 1. Lara Glover was a Marlborough Community College student. Photo: Supplied 
Mrs Glover then raced to the scene, where she would say her final goodbye. 
"I did have that moment, and I will cherish it always," Glover told Media. 
"I felt so blessed that someone had done that and very, very, very thankful." 
The 16-year-old and her friends were on their way to Picton to swim when they crashed neat Spring Creek on Sunday. A roadside memorial for Lara Glover near Spring Creek. Photo: Supplied 
Despite her daughter's death, Mrs Glover said she holds no anger or blame towards anyone. 
"They all have to live with the fact they had an accident which resulted in my daughter's death, I don't want them to carry a burden for their whole life," she told Fairfax. 
"There's no blame, this was an accident." 
Lara was the youngest of seven children in the Glover family, with six brothers. Lara Glover. Photo: Supplied 
Mrs Glover described her daughter as a loyal and loving character who had many friends. 
Meanwhile, one of the three teens still in hospital has been placed in an induced coma.. 
Jordan Bosch, 17, suffered a punctured lung, ruptured spleen, a lower sine fracture and was not responding to verbal commands, Fairfax reported. 
Jordan's father Jade Bosch said they don't know if he'll be the same again. 
"It's such an early stage that we're clueless to know what to expect," he told Fairfax. 
"It's been hard going. He's fighting and nowhere near out of the woods." 
One friend was transferred to Christchurch hospital, while another remained in Wairau hospital. Both are expected to make full recoveries, while the other four passengers had been treated and discharged.
